front.title: RFC 2731 ("Encoding Dublin Core Metadata in HTML") is Obsolete

abstract.t: This document recommends that RFC 2731, on Encoding Dublin Core Metadata in HTML, be reclassified as Historic, as further development of this specification has moved to the Dublin Core Metadata Initiative.

note.title: Editorial Note (To be removed by RFC Editor before publication)
note.t: Distribution of this document is unlimited.
Please send feedback to either the DC-Architecture mailing list () or the IETF Apps Area mailing list ().
XML versions and latest edits for this document are available from .

section.title: Introduction
section.t: defines "Encoding Dublin Core Metadata in HTML". Newer specifications published by the Dublin Core Metadata Initiative (DCMI) over the last decade, in particular "Expressing Dublin Core metadata using HTML/XHTML meta and link elements" (DC-HTML, ), have obsoleted this work.

list.t: Note: Implementers of RFC 2731 should note that DC-HTML introduces a new requirement with respect to the use of the "head" element's "profile" attribute.

section.title: Recommendation to Reclassify RFC 2731
section.t: This document recommends that the IESG reclassify as Historic.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document is of adminstrative nature only and therefore there are no security relations related to it.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: There are no IANA considerations related to this document.

front.title: Encoding Dublin Core Metadata in HTML

author.organization: University of California, San Francisco, Center for Knowledge Management

section.title: Related Discussion on DC-ARCHITECTURE Mailing list (to be removed by RFC Editor before publication)
section.t: This proposal has been discussed and approved on the DC-ARCHITECTURE mailing list (, ).

section.title: Change Log (to be removed by RFC Editor before publication)
Since draft-reschke-rfc2732bis-02
section.t: Added John Kunze as Co-Author. Expand Security Considerations to say why there aren't any. Include title of RFC 2731 into this document's title. Mention that Dublin Core has maintained its version of the spec for the last decade. Add open issue "historic", which is waiting for community feedback.

section.title: Resolved issues (to be removed by RFC Editor before publication)
section.t: Issues that were either rejected or resolved in this version of this document.

section.title: edit
section.t: julian.reschke@greenbytes.de (2009-09-09): Umbrella issue for editorial fixes/enhancements.

section.title: title
section.t: ietfdbh@comcast.net (2009-09-09): Include the title of RFC 2731 into this document's title.

section.title: sec
section.t: sm@resistor.net (2009-09-10): LC feedback: explain why there are no Security Considerations.

section.title: Open issues (to be removed by RFC Editor prior to publication)
historic
section.t: julian.reschke@greenbytes.de (2009-10-08): It's not clear whether this case is really a candidate for reclassification as "historic". After all, the format that was described in RFC 2731 is still in use in Dublin Core's DC-HTML; it just got revised. So simply stating that it is obsolete (which would be implied by publishing this document) should be enough.
